awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel Extrusion System for Additive Manufacturing of Engineered Lattice Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to support the use of sustainable materials, stronger parts, and material savings in Large Format Additive Manufacturing for the Aerospace and Defense Industry. The technology has the potential to reduce printing time and energy consumption. It could also enable the printing of complex geometries at a scale not currently accessible in the manufacturing industry. 

The intellectual merit of this project is to address the two biggest technical challenges customers face in the Large Format Additive Manufacturing industry: low-strength in the Z-direction, and high surface porosity. This project is developing two innovative solutions to address these technical challenges. The first innovation is using multiple independently articulated nozzles to print a part through a non-planar printing approach. During proof-of-concept experiments, this innovation has shown success for non-planar fiber alignment. It shows the potential to improve strength in the Z-direction, by custom fiber alignment in the direction of loading. For the second innovation, a nozzle design will be developed to heat printed material through the nozzles. A prototype for this technology has already shown a 30-40% increase in strength for ASTM D-638 tensile test specimens. It is hypothesized that the increase in strength is due to decrease in porosity, improved layer bonding, and polymer entanglement, which can solve the second big challenge for Large Format Additive Manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
PRISAM conducted over 200 customer discovery interviews to understand the specific needs for sandwich panel construction in aerospace applications. The roles of these interviewees included project managers, engineers, scientists, and chief executives from tier 1 suppliers. The interviews can be further segmented into the commercial, defense, and private sectors. 

From the discussions, we found that fuel efficiency, sustainability, and cost reduction are top priorities of aircraft manufacturers and suppliers. Traditionally for sandwich panel construction, a flat aluminum honeycomb sheet is used as a core. The honeycomb panels are then formed into commercial aircraft parts which requires millions of dollars in tooling and manual labor. Institutions like NASA and MIT have demonstrated cores made from lattice unit cells can improve flight performance. The unit cells dynamically respond to the varying flight conditions as they have a mixture of stiff and flexible elements. An airframe with stiff and flexible elements can fly more efficiently because they operate like the wings of a bird. Although lattice cores are an excellent candidate to replace traditional honeycomb cores to improve flight performance, their current manufacturing process relies predominantly on manual hand assembly of its unit cells.

PRISAM's innovation, RALE (Robotic Axial Lattice Extrusion), automates the manufacturing of engineered lattice cores that cannot be made in any other way. Figure 1 shows the proof-of-concept AM (Additive Manufacturing) toolpaths, depositing material directly into 3D space without any support material. A polymer composite lattice core is presented in Figure 1(b), made with RALE. Fibers are aligned along the axial direction of each truss, as seen in Figure 1(c). Such fiber alignment significantly increases the stiffness of the lattice core while keeping the mass low.

In NSF SBIR Phase I, PRISAM completed a TRL 4 (Technology Readiness Level) hardware as that the technology has been validated in a laboratory environment. The team created and tested three iterations of this mechanism. This version seen in Figure 2 of RALE has four independently articulating nozzles mounted on a 6-axis robotic arm.

The multiple nozzles, as shown in Figure 2, produce unit cells faster compared to the single nozzle proof-of-concept shown in Figure 1. Filament extrusion-based AM processes, like the one shown in Figure 1, deposit fluid material on top of solid material resulting in weak interlayer bonding. This prevents filament extrusion parts from being used in high-strength applications like airframes.  With multiple nozzles, like in Figure 2, fluid material is fused with other fluid material. Additionally, the lattice unit cells made with multiple nozzles can have a mixture of stiff and flexible elements as demonstrated by NASA and MIT. Figure 3 also presents RALE's current version's capability to extrude different combinations of materials. RALE can therefore be tailored to create unique properties for a given application.  

Aircraft suppliers and manufacturers have found that the lattice core manufacturing process was too costly in terms of time and labor. RALE provides them key benefits like:

1. Elimination of tooling
2. Stronger bonds at the nodes of truss structure
3. Optimized and lighter structure
4. Near zero waste
5. Reduction of production time from months to days


Last Modified: 08/30/2022
Modified by: Pritam Poddar

Images (1 of )

  • Figure 3 � Robotic Axial Lattice Extrusion (RALE) of different materials resulting in a strong node bond.
